race.name: Total Tomahawk Terrain
race.tagline: Northern Wisconsin Northwoods gravel in Tomahawk.

climate.description: Variable summer conditions with potential for heat or rain.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through northern Wisconsin Northwoods. Rolling terrain with moderate elevation.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Small grassroots Wisconsin event. Affordable but very limited infrastructure and field.

biased_opinion.summary: Total Tomahawk Terrain is a small grassroots gravel race in remote northern Wisconsin. Tomahawk is tiny, amenities are basic, and the field is small. It's an honest local event with rolling Northwoods terrain and affordable pricing, but it's not trying to be more than a regional ride for Wisconsin cyclists.
weaknesses: Tiny field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A small local gravel race in remote Wisconsin. Perfect for locals who want an affordable weekend ride in the Northwoods. Not worth traveling far for unless you're combining with Wisconsin vacation.

final_verdict.one_liner: Small grassroots Wisconsin Northwoods ride with modest ambitions.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're in Wisconsin and want an affordable, low-key gravel ride in the Northwoods. Not worth traveling far for.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Wisconsin events: Chequamegon, Driftless Gravel. For similar grassroots vibes: other regional Midwest events.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Limited lodging in Tomahawk. Book early or look for nearby towns.
logistics.food: Small town with basic dining. Stock up beforehand.

history.origin_story: Grassroots gravel event in northern Wisconsin.

course_description.character: Rolling Northwoods gravel through forest and rural areas.
course_description.signature_challenge: Rolling Northwoods terrain and Wisconsin summer weather.

non_negotiables.why: Basic support means managing your own nutrition and mechanicals.

topics.execution: Race day tactics for grassroots events

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of northern Wisconsin Northwoods gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Small grassroots event in remote Tomahawk.

logistics.explanation: SARA Park provides camping, showers, and beach access, but the course is unmarked and riders navigate with paper cue sheets or GPS files. Chris Schotz serves as the sole organizer for this free ride with minimal infrastructure details available.

length.explanation: The TTT 103 offers a proper century-length challenge with resupply in Tripoli at mile 77 and lunch available in Ogema at mile 52. The Willow 63 requires complete self-support with no resupply points along its route. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The course features 74% gravel through Lincoln, Taylor, and Oneida County Forests with numerous bridges over waterways. Rail-to-trails sections on Mountain-Bay, Hiawatha, and Wiouwash Trails contain many boardwalks rather than challenging technical terrain. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The signature climb reaches Timm's Hill at mile 60, Wisconsin's highest point at 1,951 feet. The 3,000 feet of total elevation gain over the course distance provides moderate climbing without mountain-level challenges. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 76¬∞F and lows of 58¬∞F, with a 53% chance of rain on any given day. June conditions in northern Wisconsin present variable weather possibilities, but no historical race weather data is available from the research. The event had a hiatus in 2020-2021, limiting weather pattern documentation. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Timm's Hill at 1,951 feet represents Wisconsin's highest elevation, which poses zero altitude concerns. The course runs through northern Wisconsin forests at modest elevations throughout. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Riders navigate unmarked routes through remote areas including Knox Mills Ghost Town at mile 68 and Gobler Lake State Natural Area. Self-supported sections require preparation with "whatever you can buy in Tripoli and the Windmill."

prestige.explanation: IRONBULL created this "old school free gravel bike ride" during the pandemic and recognized its value as a no-entry-fee event. It remains a grassroots Wisconsin ride without professional field or media coverage.

race_quality.explanation: Shane Hitz notes that "visitors often marvel at the quality of gravel riding we have in Central Wisconsin." However, the unmarked course and minimal support infrastructure keep this as a basic self-supported adventure.

experience.explanation: The route includes an ice cream shop stop at the Windmill on Lake Nokomis before riders spin down the bike path back to SARA Park. Post-ride amenities include park showers, beach access, and camping facilities.

community.explanation: IRONBULL, a 501(c)(3) organization, maintains the free format to welcome beginners - two-thirds of riders in 2020 completed their first gravel ride. The 7th edition adds shorter routes specifically to encourage new gravel riders.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 100-250 riders, the event actively courts beginners with multiple shorter route options and focuses on accessibility over competition. No past winners or competitive talent depth is documented in the available research. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Zero entry fee for 103 miles of Wisconsin forest gravel through three county forests makes this exceptional value. IRONBULL's 501(c)(3) status enables the free format that eliminates financial barriers to participation.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-90. Free entry eliminates the primary race expense, with SARA Park camping providing affordable lodging. Riders only pay for travel costs and whatever food they purchase in Tripoli during the resupply stop. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

citations.label: silentsportsmagazine.com: Ironbull Brings More Free Gravel Riding To North Central ...

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Total Tomahawk Terrain gravel race Tomahawk

videos.title: How To Perform A Basic Bike Fit
videos.description:
The art of setting up your bike can be a complex process. Thankfully, Simon Richardson is on hand to talk you through some key bike fit adjustments to ensure your riding position is as comfortable and efficient as possible.

Subscribe to GCN on YouTube: http://gcn.eu/gcnsubs

If you're planning to spend a lot of time on your bike, it's important to be comfortable. A small amount of time spent on setting up your bike correctly can help you pedal with more efficiency and power, as well as avoid long-term injury.

Former pro cyclist Simon Richardson explains how, with just three easy adjustments at the saddle and handlebars, you can get into a position on the bike which will maximise performance and comfort.

Music: The Impellers - Close To Me (Instrumental): http://gcn.eu/178kvgd

About GCN:

The Global Cycling Network puts you in the centre of the action: from the iconic summit of the Stelvio to the epic trails of Fort William, Scotland, everywhere there is pav√© or dirt, world-class racing, and pro riders, we will be there bringing you all the action, essential analysis and unparalleled access every week, every month, and every year.

Welcome to the Global Cycling Network | Inside cycling

Youtube Channel - http://gcn.eu/gcnYT
Facebook - http://gcn.eu/gcnFb
Google+ - http://gcn.eu/gcnGPlus
Twitter - http://gcn.eu/gcnTW

Leave us a comment below!

Music licensed by Cue Songs
Music - licensed by Cue Songs
videos.transcript:
[Music]
getting your bike well set up to your
body can make the difference between
riding in comfort and riding in pain and
for those of us chasing performance it
can be the Cornerstone to reaching your
full potential now it is a complex topic
more art than science perhaps but here
is our beginner's guide to get you in
the ballpark and the first thing to get
set up is your saddle height now with
the ball of your foot over the pedal
axle and your pedal in the 6:00 position
there should be a slight Bend in your
leg now if you get your saddle too high
then it will cause your pelvis to rotate
as your foot stretches and that will
cause lower back pain and saddle
discomfort and if it's too low then
you'll lose power and you'll also get
knee pain to get the best idea of
judging your saddle position it's a good
idea to film yourself riding on a static
trainer like this because what it does
is it means that you get a better idea
of where your natural foot position is
some people ride with their heel down
some people ride with their toe down and
that difference can subtly alter the
angle of your leg
next you go for the forward and backward
adjustment of your saddle and this is
called the layback now the age-old
technique of telling whether you've got
the right amount of layback is by
putting your pedals level when you're
sat in the saddle and you drop a plum
line from the front of your kneecap and
it should drop just in front of the
pedal axle the micro adjustment of this
position can be tailored according to
whether you use your glutes
predominantly or your quads
predominantly when you're pedaling but
this is perhaps a bit more of an
advanced technique and we'll cover this
later so now we've tackled the seat
position it's time to look at the reach
now it's a common misconception that you
can adjust the reach to your handlebars
from your saddle by adjusting your
saddle position forwards and backwards
but as we've just set this up for
Optimum pedaling efficiency this needs
to be left where it is so in reality the
way you can adjust the reach is by
moving your stem up and down by up to 2
to 4 cm depending on how much steer
space you've got and then unfortunately
by just buying different length stems so
there's a reason why it's a great idea
to go to a good bike shop when you're
buying a bike in the first place as it
stops you spending money later on to
adjust your position fundamentally
though more relaxed Rider will have a
proportionately shorter reach from the
handlebars to stem and a rider looking
for a more aggressive aerodynamic
Position will have a longer one however
the limiting factor is in reality the
flexibility in your glutes and your
hamstrings so no amount of wanting to
look aerodynamic is actually going to
make it an effective position it's a
general guide though that angle of your
back should be about 45¬∞ and the angle
between your arms and your back should
be about 90¬∞ and this gives you the best
blend of comfort aerodynamics and power
when riding on the tops you can have an
even more relaxed position so it's good
for climbing but then when you're on the
drops by bending your arms you can get
your back close to horizontal if you can
stretch that far for
aerodynamics so to sum up first of all
you set your saddle height then you set
the layback and then finally leaving
that in one place you adjust the reach
to the handlebars now as we said at the
beginning bike setup is a complex topic
so it's something we're going to come
back to again and again over the coming
months and if there's something specific
that you want us to tackle with regards
to bike fit or bike problems then let us
know in the comment section down below
and we'll tackle it at a later
date single Pace line is the most
efficient way of riding if you're facing
a stiff headwind or if you're riding in
a very small group in this video we're
going to show exactly how to do
it

videos.title: Are TITANIUM Gravel Bikes Worth It?
videos.description:
Titanium is premium frame material that comes with added cost (usually). Is it worth the substantial price to have this elusive material?

Featured in this video:
Masi Incanto gravel bike from bikesonline.com
https://tinyurl.com/2xjp2wbt

Support the channel!
https://www.thebikesauce.com/
videos.transcript:
Now, when it comes to bikes and metal
framed bikes in particular, there's an
endless debate over what material is the
best or more specifically which provides
the best ride feel. Now, unfortunately,
the discussion often devolves into
pointing out very specific properties of
the materials themselves. For instance,
when discussing titanium versus steel,
it is true that titanium has lower
density, so it is lighter than steel for
the same volume of material. Titanium is
also much stronger than steel in tensile
yield and shear, which is why you
commonly hear people reciting that
titanium strength to weight ratio is
much higher than steel. Now, on the flip
side, titanium is factually not as stiff
as steel. In fact, it's only about half
as stiff as steel, which is why titanium
bike frames tend to have larger diameter
tubes in order to compensate for the
lower stiffness when compared to a
skinny tube steel counterpart. Now, of
course, these are generalized statements
about the material properties of
titanium and steel. And of course,
there's a whole slew of generalizations
about aluminum frames as well. Now, bike
frames are never produced from pure
elemental titanium or aluminum. And
believe it or not, steel isn't even an
element on the periodic table. Rather,
alloys or blends of elemental materials
are used to produce titanium, steel, and
aluminum tubing used in frame building.
And for each metal, there are different
available alloys, each with different
material properties. So the point is
that try as we might, it's really
impossible to make any generalized
statements about one material over the
other. Anyone who claims that a bike
frame made from one metal is always more
compliant or always stiffer or always
lighter than another is simply not
considering the whole picture. And in
addition to the variation of alloys,
tube diameters, and frame design from
bike to bike, we haven't even mentioned
the butdding profiles of the individual
tubes, which arguably have an equal, if
not bigger impact on the ride feel as
the material itself. Now, what is for
certain is that titanium is certainly
more challenging to work with, which
will increase production time. That
combined with the fact that titanium in
its raw form is about a hundred times
more expensive than raw steel typically
makes a complete titanium frame
substantially more expensive than a
steel counterpart. So, as promised in
the title, is splurging on a titanium
frame actually worth it? Well, obviously
no single video will hold a definitive
answer, but in this video I'll share my
thoughts on titanium bikes based on my
experiences riding several of them over
the past few years. So, this is a Masi
Encanto. It happens to be a titanium
gravel bike that Bikes Online sent over
for review, and I've been riding it
around for a few weeks now. Now, it's
not the first Thai bike that I've
demoed, and I'm sure it won't be the
last. But, as far as gravel bikes go,
this one is actually pretty par for the
course. It's designed around 700c
wheels, and the stock build comes with
40mm wide Kenda aluvium semi-naviers. It
comes with a Stram Rival Explore Access
12-speed one by drivetrain, 40 to chain
ring up front, and a 10 to 44 to
12-speed cassette in the back. The
geometry is also pretty standard for an
all-road gravel bike, if that's even a
thing. Stack of 560, reach of 384 for
this size small, which is slightly
longer and lower than I'm used to, but
it's comfortable nonetheless. It's got a
somewhat questionable head tube angle of
71.8¬∞,
which seems oddly specific. The trail is
68 mm, offering a balance of stability
and agility. Short, relatively tucked
chain stays at 425 mm and a BB drop of
74 mm. So basically, geometrically
speaking, it's a very quote unquote
average gravel bike. Again, if that's
even a thing. Nothing that stands out as
odd. And it rides really predictably.
Now, being a metal framed bike, it's not
a featherweight. And I have the weights
for a size small demo bike on screen
right now without pedals. Now, very
briefly, some things that actually stand
out on this bike. The fork is carbon,
but it does have a kind of unique shape
to it. It kind of rakes out initially
and then bends back down toward the
axle. Almost resembles like a L fork,
but without the flexi bits. Also, the
photos online show a seat post with some
setback, but mine came with a straight
seat post, which is likely just a
function of this being a size small
frame. And then, of course, the real
head turner are the handlebars. Now,
these are the coefficient gravel
handlebars. They're carbon and they're
claimed to be aerero optimized and
they're well they're just really weird.
I think the idea is to create a top
section with a lot of back sweep for
some ergonomic benefits while not
affecting the reach too much. Now
there's also convenient Garmin mount out
front and the bars are designed to be
run with internal cables. For me,
however, this is just an example of
engineering a solution to a problem that
didn't really exist and really creating
some other problems along the way. For
instance, the cable routing as a result
of this handlebar design is pretty wild.
The brake lines are routed through the
handlebars, but they come out in these
spots here, which actually makes the
cable runs to the frame really awkward.
Now, I do suppose you get that swept
back top. And if that's something that
you really want, then this bar could
potentially work for you. Although, it'd
probably work best with fully internal
cable routing through the stem and the
head tube. Now, in my case, however, I
simply had to swap the bars after a
couple of rides. And I've been running
an alloy Richie Butano bar and I've
actually been much happier with the fit.
I also swapped the saddle almost
immediately, but again, saddles are very
personal. It's just that the stock one
didn't work out for me. Okay, so other
than those few quirks, the bike actually
rides really nice. And again, we're
discussing whether titanium as a frame
material is worth the considerable
investment. And so quirky component
choices on a complete bike are a little
bit beside the point. All right, so
let's talk a little bit about ride
quality. Now, I do have to say that this
MSI rides very comfortably. It
definitely feels lively and springy over
rough terrain, very similar to some
steel bikes that I've ridden in the
past. And if you'll pardon the verbiage,
I would have to describe the ride as
damped, compliant, and muted over bumpy
terrain. These are all things that I
associate with a comfortable ride.
Rather than pinging off rocks and roots,
I almost felt as if I were sort of
plowing over them with like a nice
satisfying thud. So, I'd say that I do
feel a difference in ride quality
between this tie bike and an aluminum or
steel bike, but it is really subtle. I
felt the same way when I tested the
Blackheart All-Road Tie and aluminum
bikes back to back. Like, there is
definitely a difference, but you really
have to focus your senses to feel it.
And I also think that wide tires run at
relatively low pressures plays a really
significant role in the ride feel,
perhaps more so than the frame material
itself. Even on this Masa here, a
difference between three or four PSI in
the tires actually makes a really big
difference in ride feel. Now, what makes
it even more difficult to tease out any
differences in ride field between metals
is the fact that equivalent frames in
different metals can't actually exist.
Now, what I mean by that is you could
conceive of an experiment where you ride
a nice well-designed Thai gravel bike
and then transfer all the components
over to another frame made from, say,
steel, with everything being identical,
including the geometry, the budding
profiles of the tubes, the tube
diameters, etc. Now, those two bikes
would ride so utterly differently, there
wouldn't even be a comparison. The steel
version would be a tank, the tubes would
be entirely overbuilt, and it would
probably weigh a ton. Recall again that
steel is much stiffer than titanium. So
you can get away with running a much
smaller diameter tube for an
equivalently stiff frame. So in other
words, again, it's just really hard to
isolate the frame material between two
frames of dissimilar metals. And
ultimately, I strongly believe that the
frame design, as in geometry, budding
profile, tubing diameter has a lot
greater influence on the ride feel than
the material itself. Now, fortunately,
this MSI Encanto was designed in such a
way that all the positive properties of
titanium do tend to stand out. Again, it
does feel springy and lively, but I've
also ridden many bikes that have similar
ride characteristics that are not tie.
For instance, the Richie Outback has a
similar ride feel with this budded steel
logic tubing, noting, of course, that
the tube diameters are substantially
smaller than on the Encanto. So, if I
had to make a generalized sweeping
observation about Tai frames, I might
say that when compared to steel, Tai has
a slightly, let's say, tighter feel to
it. As in, it does tend to mute road
buzz, but in a slightly stiffer and less
damped way. Now, I have no data to back
this up, but of the handful of Thai
bikes that I've ridden, I've generally
felt that they ride similar to steel,
but perhaps not quite as damped in how
they dissipate vibrational energy. Now,
again, this could easily just be a
perceived property based on my own
unique experiences. But nonetheless,
what's generally always true is that the
difference in ride feel is always pretty
subtle. And again, with the trend of
wider, squishier tires run at lower
pressures, those differences become even
more difficult to tease out. So, what
was the title of this video? Right. Are
titanium bikes and specifically Thai
gravel bikes in this context worth it?
Well, I said earlier that no single
video is going to have a definitive
answer. But if you want titanium for the
sake of the alleged improvement in ride
feel, as in buttery smooth, springy,
damped, muted, all those adjectives,
then I'll go ahead and say outright that
no, the price jump to get on a nice tie
frame is just not going to be worth it.
I know it's a hot take, but I will be
the first to admit that ride feel isn't
everything when it comes to selecting a
frame material. People who invest in
titanium often do so knowing that a nice
steel counterpart would probably ride
equally well and cost about half as
much. But they go for the tie frame
anyways for a number of other reasons.
One of which is that titanium is
extremely corrosion resistant which is
why most titanium bikes that you see are
just a raw brushed finish. Steel on the
other hand unless it's stainless is
highly susceptible to rust and other
types of corrosion. Now, it's possible
that some people may believe that a
high-end tie frame is somehow
necessarily lighter than a high-end
steel frame, but again, that's not
actually true. Recall, because tie is
not as stiff as steel, larger diameter
tubing has to be used to produce the
same overall stiffness. So, weight is
often a wash between tie and steel. And
then, of course, the elephant in the
room, it could just be the bling factor.
Having a tie bike really does tend to
set you apart from the crowd and lets
everybody know that you're a committed,
lifelong cyclist and that you're willing
to drop big bucks on your gear. The
vanity of it is something that we don't
like to admit, but deep down if you're a
cyclist, you've got at least some amount
of pride in the aesthetic of your bike.
And buying a tie frame could just be
some kind of manifestation of that.
Anyways, my answer to the question, are
Tai bikes worth it? Is going to be a
likely upsetting it depends. If you're
looking for pure ride feel, then no. Tai
is definitely not going to be worth the
price. But there are plenty of other
reasons that investing in titanium might
be worth it to you. Now, what I'd like
to hear are your thoughts on titanium as
a frame material. Is it always worth it,
or does it depend? What are the reasons
besides ride feel that you would opt to
shell out for a tie frame? Let us know
down below. I'm legitimately curious to
know your thoughts. All right, well,
that's going to do it for this one.
Thanks again for watching and thanks for
subscribing to the channel if you
haven't already and we'll see you next

Brought to you by the world‚Äôs biggest cycling channel, the Global Cycling Network (GCN), GCN Tech is the only channel you need for all things bike tech ‚Äì past, present and future.

Simply put, we‚Äôre obsessed with tech: we seek out and showcase the best in bikes, components, tech, accessories, upgrades and more from races and events, tech shows and product launches across the globe to bring you the best in road bike technology.

We‚Äôve also got great maintenance videos to help you get the most from your bike; pro-bike tours from all the biggest races; special features and the weekly GCN Tech Show. We also take a deeper look into the future of cycling, apps, smart tech and virtual riding.

easily clean your bike in five minutes
I'm also going to show you hacks on how
you can do this with common household
objects and explain why other videos on
this subject are wrong and will damage
your paint let's
[Music]
go right you're in a rush so we're going
to start a 5 minute timer to keep things
honest let's go first thing is I'm going
to do a pre-wash of the bike with a
and rinse it down this is to get all the
loose dirt off it because if you start
doing a contact wash straight away what
that will do is mar the paint and rub
that dirt into the paint I see so many
bike wash videos do this and it's a
massive mistake you would never do this
on your car and your bike well it can
cost more than a car now if you have a
stand it's really good to put your bike
in a stand because that way you don't
have to do what I've just done there and
spin it round you can work both sides on
it easy and it stops IT falling over if
you don't have a stand place it up
against a wall like I've done
now using a pressure washer is great but
if you don't have a pressure washer just
a normal garden hose is fine the other
thing oh the other thing that you want
to do is make sure you don't pressure
wash the bearings now we're going to put
some detergent in a bucket there we go
